title: Starting a Git Repository
subtitle: Create Your First Time Machine
description:
# Creating Your First Git Repository

Every Git journey starts with a **repository** (or "repo" for short). Think of a repository as a folder that has superpowers - it can track every change made to the files inside it.

## The `git init` Command

To turn a regular folder into a Git repository, you use:

```bash
git init
```

This command:
- Creates a hidden `.git` folder that stores all version history
- Turns your folder into a time machine for your code
- Only needs to be run once per project

## Checking Repository Status

Once you have a repository, you'll constantly want to know: *"What's the current state of my files?"*

The `git status` command is your best friend:

```bash
git status
```

This tells you:
- Which files have been modified
- Which files are ready to be saved (staged)
- Which files Git isn't tracking yet
- What branch you're on (we'll learn about branches later)

## Example Workflow

```bash
# Create a new directory
mkdir my-project
cd my-project

# Initialize Git
git init

# Check status
git status
```

You'll see output like:
```
Initialized empty Git repository in /path/to/my-project/.git/
```

And when you run `git status`:
```
On branch main
No commits yet
nothing to commit (create/copy files and use "git add" to track)
```
